pageData.text: This investigation explores <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button> and the relationship between force and <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button>. In the activity, the mass of a plastic cart is increased by adding weights in the form of washers. The cart is attached by a string to a hanging mass suspended over a pulley. As mass is transferred from the cart to the suspended weight, the cart is accelerated at an increasing rate. Students use graphical analysis to study the relationship between force and acceleration described by Newton’s second law.

text: Define force according to <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button>.
Describe the relationship between force, mass, and <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> through graphical analysis.
Measure force, calculate weight, and relate it to the SI unit of force, the <button class='glossary-text'>Newton (N)</button>.

pageData.text: Radiotherapy is a common method used to treat cancers. It involves sending a beam of radioactive particles to disrupt the DNA of cancer cells. These particles must penetrate the body, sometimes through many layers of tissues in order to reach the target cells and must, therefore, be travelling at high speeds. To reach these speeds, the particles are put through a particle accelerator that uses electric fields to exert a force on the mass of the particle and accelerate it up to high speeds. Radiation therapies can use a variety of particles, photons, electrons, or protons, depending on the treatment needed. Electrons have a very small mass, 9.11 x10-31 kg, and so the force needed to accelerate them is lower. However, this also means that the forces that the electrons encounter in the body from collisions with other particles and the electrostatic attraction of other electrons can more easily slow them down. This makes electrons effective for tumors on or near the skin, but not in deep tissues. While their use is not yet wide-spread, proton beams are increasingly being used to treat deep tissue tumors because, while they require more electric force to accelerate, they are heavier and so are harder to slow down or scatter from forces as they more through the body1.

1Mohan, R., & Grosshans, D. (2017). Proton therapy – present and future. Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews, 109,26–44.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.addr.2016.11.006

pageData.desc: A doctor attending to a patient lying prone within the arch of a radiotherapy machine in a hospital.
pageData.altText: A doctor attending to a patient lying prone within the arch of a radiotherapy machine in a hospital.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Classical mechanics</button> is the branch of physics concerned with analyzing forces, their impact on matter, and the motion of objects. The distinction “classical” means that these laws apply to systems where the effects of relativity are negligible or have little measurable impact. This is the case for most of the physical events we witness, because relativistic effects apply to objects moving near the speed of light. Most mechanical systems we study on Earth can be analyzed and described in terms of classical mechanics. Classical mechanics refers to the motion of objects that are large compared to subatomic particles and slow compared to the speed of light. The effects of <button class='glossary-text'>quantum mechanics</button> and relativity are negligible in classical mechanics.

pageData.subTitle: Newton’s Laws
pageData.text: Classical mechanics is sometimes referred to as Newtonian mechanics because much of the science builds on the work of Isaac Newton, the English physicist and mathematician who lived from 1642 until 1726. When people hear the name Newton, they are likely to think of , which they may be familiar with in one form or another. These three laws describe the relationship between force, object, mass, and motion. Newton’s laws of motion are some of the most fundamental principles of physics and are crucial to the development of modern technology. Everything from the motion of planets to the operation of sophisticated engines and machines is governed by these three simple laws.

<button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s first law of motion</button> relates to the concept of <button class='glossary-text'>inertia</button>, an object’s resistance to a change in motion. The first law states that an object’s motion remains unchanged unless the object is acted upon by an unbalanced force (i.e., net force).

A book resting on a table is being acted on by opposing and equal forces. Gravity pulls down on the book, while the table pushes up on the book with an equal amount of force. The book will remain motionless until the forces are unbalanced. Consider a rocket fired into space. In space, without friction from air resistance, once the thrust from the rocket engine stops, the rocket itself will continue to travel at a constant speed in a straight line unless the rocket is acted upon by another force. This could happen if the rocket struck another object, such as an asteroid, or if the rocket entered the gravity field of a planet causing the rocket’s path to curve.
states that the force acting on an object is related to the change in the object’s , which is the product of the object’s multiplied by its . Δp = mv
Because the mass of the object remains the same, the net force changes the object’s velocity. A change in velocity is defined as , and Newton’s second law is often described mathematically as:

pageData.desc: Equation 1: Capital F equals m times a
pageData.altText: Equation 1: Capital F equals m times a

pageData.text: Where F is the net force acting on an object, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration of the object due to the net force.
Force is measured in units of , where 1 Newton is equal to 1 kilogram multiplied by 1 m/s2. So:

pageData.desc: Equation 2: Begin equation begin bracket vector F end bracket equals N end equation, begin equation 1 N equals 1 kilogram times 1 meter per second squared end equation
pageData.altText: Equation 2: Begin equation begin bracket vector F end bracket equals N end equation, begin equation 1 N equals 1 kilogram times 1 meter per second squared end equation

pageData.text: In physics texts, vector quantities are usually indicated by printing an arrow over the variable representing the quantity, or as in this manual, placing the letter in bold italics. In the equation: F = ma
The symbols for force and are in bold italics because these quantities are vectors, while mass, represented by the letter m, is a quantity.
When a variable is written without bold print or between absolute value bars, only the magnitude of a variable is indicated. a = 9.8 m/s2
The symbol a represents an acceleration of 9.8 m/s2 in the positive direction: |a | = 9.8 m/s2
The symbol a inside absolute value bars indicates an acceleration of 9.8 m/s2 but does not specify a direction.
To indicate the units of a quantity, the variable representing the quantity is placed in brackets: [F ] = N
This indicates that the quantity (force) is measured in units of Newtons.

Consider Figure 1. A force of 20 N is acting on an object with mass of 4 kg. The of the object is 5 m/s2. In Figure 2, there is a 20 N force applied in the forward direction and a 4 N force applied in the backward direction. Therefore, the net force acting on the 4 kg object is 16 N. The acceleration is 4 m/s2. It should be noted that in this activity friction is ignored, but in reality, frictional forces are always present, and frictional forces should be considered in order to calculate the net force.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 5 meters per second squared
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 5 meters per second squared

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons as well as a backward force of 4 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 4 meters per second squared
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons as well as a backward force of 4 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 4 meters per second squared

pageData.text: So, if we substitute the net force of 16 N acting on the object, and the known mass of the object, 4 kg, into the basic equation of Newton’s second law, F = ma, we can determine the object’s acceleration: 16 N = 4 kg × 4 m/s2

pageData.question: Which of the following is measured in Newtons (N)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Force is measured in SI units of Newtons (N), where 1 Newton is equal to 1 kilogram multiplied by 1 m/s<sup>2</sup>.

pageData.question: What is the formula for calculating the net force acting on an object (F )?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The net force acting on an object (F ) equals the mass of the object (m ) times the acceleration of the object due to the net force (a ).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Force (F ) refers to the net force acting on an object, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration of the object due to the net force. The Newton (N) is named after Isaac Newton; it is the unit with which force is measured, where 1 Newton is equal to 1 kilogram multiplied by 1 m/s2. Newton’s second law of motion states that the force acting on an object is related to the change in the object’s momentum (Δp ), which is the product of the object’s mass (m ) multiplied by its velocity (v ). Because the mass of the object remains the same, the net force changes the object’s velocity.

img.alt: Equation 2: Begin equation begin bracket vector F end bracket equals N end equation, begin equation 1 N equals 1 kilogram times 1 meter per second squared end equation

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Force (F ) refers to the net force acting on an object, m is the mass of the object, and a is the acceleration of the object due to the net force. The Newton (N) is named after Isaac Newton; it is the unit with which force is measured, where 1 Newton is equal to 1 kilogram multiplied by 1 m/s2. Newton’s second law of motion states that the force acting on an object is related to the change in the object’s momentum (Δp ), which is the product of the object’s mass (m ) multiplied by its velocity (v ). Because the mass of the object remains the same, the net force changes the object’s velocity.

img.alt: Equation 2: Begin equation begin bracket vector F end bracket equals N end equation, begin equation 1 N equals 1 kilogram times 1 meter per second squared end equation

pageData.text: On Earth, the due to gravity is 9.8 m/s2. The weight (W ) of an object is calculated by multiplying the mass of the object by the acceleration due to gravity, represented by the symbol g:

pageData.desc: Equation 3: g equals 9.8 meters per second squared
pageData.altText: Equation 3: g equals 9.8 meters per second squared

pageData.text: The weight of a 10 kg object would be 98 N:

pageData.desc: Equation 4: capital W equals m times g equals bracket 10 kilograms close bracket times bracket 9.8 meter per second squared close bracket, equals 98 capital N
pageData.altText: Equation 4: capital W equals m times g equals bracket 10 kilograms close bracket times bracket 9.8 meter per second squared close bracket, equals 98 capital N

pageData.text: can help analyze mechanical systems. The force acting on an object or part of a system can be calculated by applying Newton’s laws. These equations can also be used to calculate the acceleration that an object will experience due to an applied force.

Note: The expression “net force” means the vector sum of all the forces acting on an object. If the net force on an object is zero, there will be no acceleration. The object would either remain still or move at a constant speed in a straight line. A change in the velocity of an object in any direction and/or speed is the result of a net or unbalanced force being applied to that object.

Newton's second law is at play in our lives every time we accelerate. Whether taking off in an airplane, or riding in an elevator, we experience net forces all the time. Simply walking, throwing a ball to a friend, riding a skateboard, etc., are all examples of forces at work in our everyday lives.

<button class='glossary-text'>Newton's third law of motion</button> states that forces occur in pairs. For every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force. The forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

If a person jumps off a boat that is floating in the water, as the person moves in one direction, the boat moves in the opposite direction. Also, the person does not move as far from their starting position as they would have if they had jumped from a stationary pier.

In this activity, you will construct a system consisting of a hanging mass attached to a wheeled cart and graphically analyze the relationship between the mass of the system and the force acting to accelerate the system.

pageData.question: On Earth, what is the acceleration due to gravity?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: On Earth, the acceleration due to gravity is 9.8 m/s<sup>2</sup>.

pageData.question: A book on a table at rest will remain at rest until which of the following takes place?

options.text: an unbalanced force is applied to the book
the net force applied to the book equals the acceleration of the object due to earth’s gravity
the net force applied to the book is less than zero
the acceleration of the object due to gravity changes
the weight of the object changes

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A book on a table will remain at rest until an unbalanced force is applied to the book.

The book will remain motionless until the forces are unbalanced. Consider a rocket fired into space. In space, without friction from air resistance, once the thrust from the rocket engine stops, the rocket itself will continue to travel at a constant speed in a straight line unless the rocket is acted upon by another force. This could happen if the rocket struck another object, such as an asteroid, or if the rocket entered the gravity field of a planet causing the rocket’s path to curve.

pageData.altText: A workflow map of the investigation.  To prepare, set up the pulley on the table. Start the activity by setting up the cart with the string, then label and measure the track. Then, add washers to the cart and string, measure the mass of the cart-washer system, release the cart, and observe the system. If the cart does not accelerate when released, transfer a washer from the cart to the string. Once the cart accelerates, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After 3 trials, transfer another washer from the cart to the string, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After completing 3 trials each for all of the washers, calculate the force and acceleration. Next, graph force versus acceleration to determine the experimental mass of the system. Finally, calculate the percent difference between the experimental and actual mass of the system.
pageData.desc: A workflow map of the investigation.  To prepare, set up the pulley on the table. Start the activity by setting up the cart with the string, then label and measure the track. If the cart does not accelerate when released, transfer a washer from the cart to the string. Once the cart accelerates, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After 3 trials, transfer another washer from the cart to the string, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After completing 3 trials each for all of the washers, calculate the force and acceleration. Next, graph force versus acceleration to determine the experimental mass of the system. Finally, calculate the percent difference between the experimental and actual mass of the system.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment described in the Safety and Activity section.

Safety goggles should be worn during this lab. The activities in this lab involve carts containing unsecured metal masses that move and accelerate. Take care while performing these lab activities to avoid injuring hands and fingers or feet and toes with moving or falling masses. Make sure lab area is clear of pets, children, and breakable objects.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.subTitle: Alternate Methods for Collecting Data Using Digital Devices
pageData.text: Much of the uncertainty in physics experiments arises from human reaction time error in measuring the times of events. Some of the time intervals are very short, which increases the effect of human error due to reaction time.

Observing the experiment from a good vantage point that removes parallax errors and recording measurements for multiple trials helps to minimize error; using a digital device as an alternate method of data collection may further minimize error. Many digital devices, such as smartphones and tablets, have cameras and software that allow the user to pause or slow down the video. If you film the activity against a scale such as a tape measure, you can use your video playback program to record position and time data. This can provide more accurate data and may eliminate the need for multiple trials.

If the time on your device’s playback program is not sufficiently accurate, you may download an app such as the following free apps:
  • OnForm
    iOS and Android
  • SloPro
    iOS
    Android
Or you may upload the video to your computer. Your operating system or software suite may include video playback programs, or these programs may be available for download.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes inertia?

options.text: an object’s resistance to a change in its motion
an object staying at rest despite unbalanced forces acting upon it
the unbalanced forces acting on an object
the mass times the acceleration of an object
the force of gravity attracting all objects toward the Earth

assestmentData.question: An 11 kg box is pushed with a force of 55 N. What is the acceleration of the box?
The SI unit Newtons (N) is equivalent to which of the following?
Two students are pushing a box. Student A is pushing with 10 N to the right and Student B is pushing 15 N to the right. What is the net force on the box?
If you double the force applied on an object, but keep the mass the same, what will happen to that object’s acceleration?

options.text: This is impossible; the mass cannot stay the same.

assestmentData.question: An object on Earth has a mass of 30 kg. What is the weight of the object?
You measure the mass of a washer to be 7.81 g. What is the mass of the wash in kilograms?
Which of the following is NOT a safety concern for this lab?

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Gather items listed in the Materials section.
Find a table at least 60 centimeters high.
Clear a space on the table top approximately 1‒2 meters in length and at least 10 centimeters wide. The area should be level and smooth.

The clamp pulley should attach to the end of the table with enough space for a suspended mass to fall unobstructed to the floor. See Figure 3 for an example of the clamp pulley secured to a tabletop. You may place a piece of cardboard between the clamp and the table to prevent damaging the table surface.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Activity 1 setup which shows a clamp pully system secured to a table top; a thread runs through the pully, and on the end of the thread hangs a washer attached with a paper clip
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Activity 1 setup which shows a clamp pully system secured to a table top; a thread runs through the pully, and on the end of the thread hangs a washer attached with a paper clip

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will increase the mass of a plastic cart adding weights in the form of washers. You will observe the change in <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> of the cart in response to the increased weight and graph the data to determine the relationship between force and acceleration described by <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button>.
Remove the rubber stopper and circular spring from the cart if attached.
Important: Use caution when removing the spring, as it can decompress quickly and become a projectile.
Tie a string to the cart through the hole where the rubber stopper was attached.

Place 2 books close together on the table near the clamp pulley, one on either side of the string. Place them close enough to the clamp to prevent the cart from running into the pulley. Make sure the books do not interfere with the movement of the string.
Place the cart on the table so the front edge rests against the stopping books.
Thread the string over the pulley and down to the floor.
Unbend a paper clip to make a hook where you can suspend the washers. See Figure 3.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Activity 1 setup which shows a clamp pully system secured to a table top; a thread runs through the pully, and on the end of the thread hangs a washer attached with a paper clip

pageData.text: Note: you will have to suspend multiple washers (as indicated in Data Table 1) for various trials before you conduct the experiment and take readings.

Cut the string near the floor and tie the free end of the string to the paper clip. When the front edge of the cart rests against the books and the string is threaded over the pulley, the paper clip and the washers should be suspended just above the floor.

Roll the cart backward on the table away from the books and pulley, until the paper clip is just below, but not touching, the pulley. Place a piece of tape in front of the front edge of the cart (see the start point indicated in Figure 4). Label this tape as “start point” or “d = 0.”

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A diagram showing the table top and pully set up; a cart with washers is shown on the table with its intended travel pattern, showing the start point and the end point of its journey.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A diagram showing the table top and pully set up; a cart with washers is shown on the table with its intended travel pattern, showing the start point and the end point of its journey.

pageData.text: Place a second piece of tape on the table, across the path of the cart and even with the stopping books. Label this tape as “end point.”

With the tape measure, measure the displacement from the start point to the end point. If you measure the displacement in centimeters (cm) divide the number by 100 to convert the number to meters. Record this value in Data Table 1 as “s (m).” This value will be the same for all trials.
Add 6 large washers and 5 small washers to the cart. Add 3 small washers to the paper clip on the end of the string.

Using the pocket scale, measure the combined mass of the cart with all the washers, the string, and the paper clip. This is the “mass of the system,” and this mass will remain constant during the experiment. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Note: Your scale measures in grams. All masses should be converted to kilograms (kg). To convert a gram to a kilogram, divide the mass in grams by 1000.
Place the cart behind the piece of tape, marking the start point, and suspend the paper clip with the initial 4 small washers over the pulley (see Figure 4).
Release the system and allow the suspended mass to fall. If the system does not move, transfer one of the smaller washers from the cart to the paper clip hook.

Once you have successfully set up the system with the initial conditions that will allow the suspended mass to accelerate the cart, use the pocket scale and measure the mass of the paper clip with the small washers. Record this value in Data Table 1.

Set up the cart, string, and suspended mass system again so that the mass on the paper clip is suspended from the pulley and the cart is immediately behind the start point as shown in Figure 4. The string should be taut enough so that there is no slack.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Release the cart and simultaneously start the stopwatch. Stop the stopwatch when the cart contacts the stopping books.
Record the time in Data Table 1.
Repeat Steps 16−18 two more times for a total of three trials using the same number of washers to accelerate the system. Record the times for the three in Data Table 1.
Move one of the small washers from the cart to the paper clip.
Repeat the procedure in Steps 15−21, collecting data for three trials with the mass of an additional washer accelerating the system until 7 washers are suspended from the paper clip.
Calculate the force (N) accelerating the cart by multiplying the mass of the suspended washers and the paper clip by the due to gravity g = 9.8 m/s2 ).
Note: Mass is the amount of matter in an object. Weight is the force of gravity on an object, which is provided in Newtons, N: weight = force due to gravity = mg W = FG = mg
Calculate the average time of the three trials for each iteration of the experiment. Add the times together and divide by 3 to get the average.
Calculate the square of each average time (t 2).

Calculate the acceleration of the system by using the kinematic equation: Δx = 1/2 a t 2 Where Δx is displacement (the distance that the cart moved from the start point to the end point), t 2 is the square of the time for the cart to move from the start point to the end point (in this experiment three times are averaged to minimize error) and a is the acceleration of the system. Rearranging the preceding equation for acceleration gives:

pageData.desc: Equation 5: Acceleration equals begin fraction 2 delta x over time squared end fraction
pageData.altText: Equation 5: Acceleration equals begin fraction 2 delta x over time squared end fraction

pageData.text: As the mass that is suspended over the pulley increases, the weight, or the force, accelerating the system increases, and therefore the acceleration of the system increases.

Use graph paper or graphing software to construct a graph of force (N) vs. acceleration (m/s2). The force accelerating the system in each trial is the weight of the suspended mass. The slope of the line should be the mass of the entire system. According to , the relationship between force and acceleration is given by : F = ma Force is the y value in the graph and acceleration is the x value.
Calculate the percent difference between the mass of the system determined experimentally using the slope of the line and the mass you recorded using the pocket scale.

pageData.desc: Equation 6: Percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end fraction end absolute value times 100 percent
pageData.altText: Equation 6: Percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

pageData.content: Figure 1. Acceleration of a mass being acted on by a single force
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 5 meters per second squared

pageData.content: Figure 2. Acceleration of a mass being acted on by two opposing forces
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing a forward force of 20 Newtons as well as a backward force of 4 Newtons acting on an object with a mass of 4 kilograms, yielding an acceleration of 4 meters per second squared

pageData.content: Equation 3. Value of gravity on Earth
pageData.altText: Equation 3: g equals 9.8 meters per second squared
Equation 4: capital W equals m times g equals bracket 10 kilograms close bracket times bracket 9.8 meter per second squared close bracket, equals 98 capital N

A workflow map of the investigation.  To prepare, set up the pulley on the table. Start the activity by setting up the cart with the string, then label and measure the track. Then, add washers to the cart and string, measure the mass of the cart-washer system, release the cart, and observe the system. If the cart does not accelerate when released, transfer a washer from the cart to the string. Once the cart accelerates, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After 3 trials, transfer another washer from the cart to the string, measure the final mass of the washers on the string, release the cart, and measure the time it takes to reach the ground. After completing 3 trials each for all of the washers, calculate the force and acceleration. Next, graph force versus acceleration to determine the experimental mass of the system. Finally, calculate the percent difference between the experimental and actual mass of the system.
Figure 3: Activity 1 setup which shows a clamp pully system secured to a table top; a thread runs through the pully, and on the end of the thread hangs a washer attached with a paper clip
Figure 4: A diagram showing the table top and pully set up; a cart with washers is shown on the table with its intended travel pattern, showing the start point and the end point of its journey.

pageData.content: Equation 5. Acceleration for a given displacement and time where initial velocity is zero
pageData.altText: Equation 5: Acceleration equals begin fraction 2 delta x over time squared end fraction

Equation 6: Percent difference equals begin absolute value begin fraction first value minus second value over begin paren first value plus second value over 2 end paren end fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

data.title: Acceleration
data.content: A change in an object’s velocity

data.title: Classical mechanics
data.content: The branch of physics concerned with analyzing forces, their impact on matter, and the motion of objects

data.title: Inertia
data.content: The tendency of an object to resist change to its motion unless acted upon by a net or unbalanced force

data.title: Mass (m)
data.content: The quantity of matter in a physical body

data.title: Momentum (Δp)
data.content: A vector, the quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity

data.title: Newton (N)
data.content: The SI unit of force; the amount of force needed to accelerate 1 kilogram (kg) of mass at a rate of 1 meter per second squared (m/s<sup>2</sup>)

data.title: Newton’s first law of motion
data.content: States that every object will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change its state by the action of an external force

data.title: Newton’s laws of motion
data.content: Three laws that describe the relationship between force, object, mass, and motion

data.title: Newton’s second law of motion
data.content: States that the force acting on an object is related to the change in the object’s momentum (Δp), which is the product of the object’s mass (m) multiplied by its velocity (v)

data.title: Newton's third law of motion
data.content: States that forces occur in pairs, for every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force, the forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction

data.title: Quantum mechanics
data.content: The branch of mechanics that deals with the mathematical description of the physical properties of nature at the scale of atoms and subatomic particles

data.title: Scalar
data.content: Describes a quantity that has a magnitude but not a direction

data.title: Velocity (v)
data.content: The rate of change of the position of an object, refers to both the speed and direction of an object, a vector quantity
